questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription that contains a Microsoft Defender External Attack Surface Management (Defender EASM) resource named EASM1. EASM1 has discovery enabled and contains several inventory assets.

You need to identify which inventory assets are vulnerable to the most critical web app security risks.

Which Defender EASM dashboard should you use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/external-attack-surface-management/understanding-dashboards#owasp-top-10-dashboard

Answer: B
Explanation:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/external-attack-surface-management/understandingdashboards#
owasp-top-10-dashboard

Selected Answer: B
B. OWASP Top 10
Open Web Application Security Project : OWASP

Selected Answer: B
The OWASP Top 10 dashboard is designed to provide insight on the most critical security recommendations as designated by OWASP, a reputable open-source foundation for web application securit

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
web app->B

choices.C: Manually add the Azure CIS 1.4.0 standard.
choices.B: Disable one of the Out of the box standards.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
To assign an Azure policy for the Azure CIS 1.4.0 standard:
1. Go to the Azure portal.
2. Click Security Center.
3. Click Regulatory compliance.
4. Click Add standard.
5. Select Azure CIS 1.4.0 and click Add.
6. Select the scope of the policy and click Assign.

The question is about 'What should you do first', so do the 'add' before 'assign'.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.
However, Azure policy is confusing. On MDC, the name is security policy.

Selected Answer: C
Manually add the Azure CIS 1.4.0 standard. Its not added by default.
By default, there are:
PCI DSS, ISO 27001, SOC TSP and Microsoft Cloud Security Benchmark.

Selected Answer: C
Manually add the Azure CIS 1.4.0 standard. Its not added by default.

Selected Answer: C
#6 From the Add regulatory compliance standards page, you can search for any of the available standards: Screenshot showing adding regulatory standards to regulatory compliance dashboard. 

#7 Select Add and enter all the necessary details for the specific initiative such as scope, parameters, and remediation.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/defender-for-cloud/update-regulatory-compliance-packages
THE STATNDARDS ARE ASSIGNED TO THE SECURITY POLICY. SOME EVEN COME ASSIGNED BY DEFAULT. YOU ASSIGN A POLICY BEFORE YOU CAN MANUALLY ADD THE STANDARD. (A) IS CORRECT.

Selected Answer: C
C. Manually add the Azure CIS 1.4.0 standard

Azure CIS 1.4.0 standard is not added by default, you have to add it manually.

Note: You must have Defender Cloud Security Posture Management (CSPM). Foundational CSPM propably is not enough.

comments.content:
C is correct

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/defender-for-cloud/update-regulatory-compliance-packages

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Manually add the Azure CIS 1.4.0 standard.

comments.content:

Add Azure CIS 1.4.0 standard initiative

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription that uses Microsoft Defender for Cloud.

You need to use Defender for Cloud to review regulatory compliance with the Azure CIS 1.4.0 standard. The solution must minimize administrative effort.

What should you do first?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
TDE protector can only be an asymmetric, RSA, or RSA HSM key. The supported key lengths are 2048 bytes and 3072 bytes.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/transparent-data-encryption-byok-overview?view=azuresql#requirements-for-configuring-tde-protector

Selected Answer: E
E. Key1 and Key2 only
tested in lab EC is greyed out and 4096 is greyed out as well

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/transparent-data-encryption-byok-overview?view=azuresql#requirements-for-configuring-tde-protector

RSA or RSA HSM key; supported length is either 2048 or 3072

correct, https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/transparent-data-encryption-byok-overview?view=azuresql#requirements-for-configuring-tde-protector

Selected Answer: E
Key lengths supported are 2048 and 3072 therefor answer E for sure

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription that contains an Azure SQL database named SQL1 and an Azure key vault named KeyVault1. KeyVault1 stores the keys shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You need to configure Transparent Data Encryption (TDE). TDE will use a customer-managed key for SQL1.
Which keys can you use?

questions.answer_description: The backups can only be restored to key vaults in the same subscription and same geography. You can restore to a different region in the same geography.
questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have the Azure key vaults shown in the following table.
//IMG//

KV1 stores a secret named Secret1 and a key for a managed storage account named Key1.
You back up Secret1 and Key1.
To which key vaults can you restore each backup? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
I will go with the given answers -"When you back up a key vault object, such as a secret, key, or certificate, the backup operation will download the object as an encrypted blob. This blob can't be decrypted outside of Azure. To get usable data from this blob, you must restore the blob into a key vault within the same Azure subscription and Azure geography
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/key-vault/general/backup

comments.content: Yep, same Azure subscription and Azure geography including the paired region.

discussion.content:
Restore the Secret1: KV1, KV2 and KV3
Restore the Key1: KV1, KV2 and KV3
i thnink that before you pass an azure certification exam you should have skills in geography ...

comments.content:
..and english proficiency as 'geography' may be understood differently. 
Azure Geography:

Definition: A geography is a grouping of Azure regions that adhere to data residency and compliance requirements specific to a particular country or group of countries. Azure geographies ensure that data residency, sovereignty, and compliance needs are met according to local laws and regulations.

discussion.content: The backups can only be restored to key vaults in the same subscription and same geography. You can restore to a different region in the same geography.

if these conditions meets, so its possible 
-Both of the Azure regions belong to the same geography.
-Both of the key vaults belong to the same Azure subscription.

The answers are correct.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/key-vault/general/overview-security-worlds#:~:text=own%20security%20worlds.-,Backup%20and%20restore%20behavior,to%20the%20same%20Azure%20subscription.

Answers are correct.
 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/key-vault/general/backup?tabs=azure-cli#design-considerations
"When you back up a key vault object, such as a secret, key, or certificate, the backup operation will download the object as an encrypted blob. This blob can't be decrypted outside of Azure. To get usable data from this blob, you must restore the blob into a key vault within the same Azure subscription and Azure geography."
 
West/East US are in the same geography (United States) : https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/explore/global-infrastructure/geographies/#geographies
So only subscription matters here.

When you back up a key vault object, such as a secret, key, or certificate, the backup operation will download the object as an encrypted blob. This blob can't be decrypted outside of Azure. To get usable data from this blob, you must restore the blob into a key vault within the same Azure subscription and Azure geography. This why KV3 cannot be used .

comments.content:
The answers are correct.
Same Geography, not same region. United States in one single geography in Azure portal.
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/explore/global-infrastructure/geographies/#geographies

"same geography" so US East/West all come under one geography - USA. Any Comments?

comments.content: Yes, same subscription and same geography (US) but can be in different regions (East US & West US).

discussion.content: Correct answers, same subscription and geography (not region)
In exam Dec 21. 40 questions, 1 case study, no labs.

comments.content: Were there any Simulation in exam?

discussion.content: In Exam 8/4/2021

Answers are correct,

When you back up a key vault object, such as a secret, key, or certificate, the backup operation will download the object as an encrypted blob. This blob can't be decrypted outside of Azure. To get usable data from this blob, you must restore the blob into a key vault within the same Azure subscription and Azure geography

Answers are correct.
When you back up a key vault object, such as a secret, key, or certificate, the backup operation will download the object as an encrypted blob. This blob can't be decrypted outside of Azure. To get usable data from this blob, you must restore the blob into a key vault within the same Azure subscription and Azure geography.
Why the answer include KV3? KV1 and KV2 are in West US but KV3 is in East US.

comments.content: Missed out this - You can restore to a different region in the same geography.
Totally correct as per: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/key-vault/general/backup?tabs=azure-cli
United states is a geography itself

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Never -
Password1 is disabled.
Box 2: Only between March 1, 2019 and May 1,
Password2:

Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/azurerm.keyvault/set-azurekeyvaultsecretattribute
questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have an Azure subscription that contains an Azure key vault named Vault1.
On January 1, 2019, Vault1 stores the following secrets. All dates are in mm/dd/yy format.
//IMG//

When can each secret be used by an application? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content:
Thank you for the wooyourdaddy.
This is the support link.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/key-vault/secrets/about-secrets

discussion.content:
Box1: Never
Box2: Only between March 1, 2019 and May 1, 2019
 
-Enable
Indicates whether to enable a secret. Specify $False to disable a secret, or $True to enable a secret. If you do not specify this parameter, there is no change to the current secret's enabled or disabled state.
 
-Expires
Specifies the date and time that a secret expires.
 
-NotBefore
Specifies the Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) before which the secret can't be used. If you do not specify this parameter, there is no change to the current secret's NotBefore attribute.

1 - Never (disabled)
2 - Always
Attributes in secrets are informational purposes only
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/key-vault/secrets/about-secrets

comments.content: correct. tested with az keyvault secret show: while retrieving a disabled secret says "Operation get is not allowed on a disabled secret", an expired secret value is returned.

I think 2 is wrong. 

enabled: boolean, optional, default is true. This attribute specifies whether the secret data can be retrieved. The enabled attribute is used in conjunction with nbf and exp when an operation occurs between nbf and exp, it will only be permitted if enabled is set to true. Operations outside the nbf and exp window are automatically disallowed, except in particular situations.

so if enabled is set to true, nbf and exp will be respected.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/key-vault/secrets/about-secrets#date-time-controlled-operations
correction: 2 is always, because it is always allowed to get the secret if enabled set to turn
true*.

enabled: boolean, optional, default is true. This attribute specifies whether the secret data can be retrieved. The enabled attribute is used with nbf and exp when an operation occurs between nbf and exp, it will only be permitted if enabled is set to true. 

Operations outside the nbf and exp window are automatically disallowed, except in particular situations.

discussion.content:
Box1 - Never - disabled 
Box2 - Always - enabled - attributes do not impose restrictions, they are just informational. 
Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/key-vault/secrets/about-secrets#secret-attributes
On exam 1/2/24

Date-time controlled operations
A secret's get operation will work for not-yet-valid and expired secrets, outside the nbf / exp window. Calling a secret's get operation, for a not-yet-valid secret, can be used for test purposes. Retrieving (getting) an expired secret, can be used for recovery operations.

comments.content:
Box1 is never
Box 2 is Always

discussion.content:
Box1: Never - (enabled=$false)
Box2: Always - fields Expires and NotBefore ar for INFORMATION purpose ONLY

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/key-vault/secrets/about-secrets"

Box 1: Never -
Password1 is disabled.
Box 2: Only between March 1, 2019 and May 1, Password2:
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/azurerm.keyvault/set-azurekeyvaultsecretatt
In exam 13 Oct

Password 1: Never (not enabled)
Password 2: Always

Given answers are correct. For Password2, it's a use by application (not any user accessing it with Get, List etc permissions - this access has nothing to do with -NotBefore) and cannot be access out of the date range applied. 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/azurerm.keyvault/set-azurekeyvaultsecretattribute?view=azurermps-2.5.0
- read description of NotBefore as below, 
Specifies the Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) before which the secret can't be used. If you do not specify this parameter, there is no change to the current secret's NotBefore attribute.
